revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = The Dell | image = The Dell.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = Exterior of the Dell in 2000 | location = Milton Road, Southampton, Hampshire, England | coordinates = {{coord|50|54|53|N|001|24|47|W|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:GB|name=The Dell|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1897 | opened = September 1898 | renovated = | expanded = 1927, 1929, 1980s, 1990s | closed = May 2001 | demolished = June – 13 July 2001 | owner = [[Southampton Leisure Holdings PLC]] | operator = [[Southampton F.C.]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = £7,000 – £9,000 | architect = [[Archibald Leitch]] (the West Stand) | tenants = [[Southampton F.C.]] (1898–2001) | events = [[Association football|Football]] | seating_capacity = 15,200{{cite web | title=The Dell's page on worldstadia| url=http://www.worldstadia.com/stadium/england/the_dell/1594.php| publisher=worldstadia.com}} | dimensions = |constructor=}} '''The Dell''' in Milton Road, [[Southampton]], Hampshire, England was the home ground of [[Southampton F.C.]] between 1898 and 2001. ==New stadium== Since 1896, Southampton had been tenants of [[Hampshire County Cricket Club]] at [[County Ground, Southampton|the County Ground]], having vacated the [[Antelope Ground]] in the summer of 1896. The rent payable to the cricket club (£200 p.a.) was putting a strain on the football club's finances and, in an attempt to reduce this burden, the club had considered a merger with [[Freemantle F.C.|the Freemantle club]] and a move to their ground in [[Shirley, Southampton|Shirley]]. The merger proposals had fallen through, but at the [[Extraordinary general meeting]] in June 1897, the members were informed that "''the committee had a ground in view''".{{cite book | title=Full-Time at The Dell |last= Juson |first=Dave|author2=Bull, David | publisher=Hagiology Publishing | year=2001| isbn=0-9534474-2-1|pages=41–42}} At a shareholders' meeting on 11 November 1897, the chairman stated:
. . . that all being well, by next season the company would be in possession of its own ground which was at the present time in the hands of George Thomas Esq. who was devoting his time to its early completion.{{cite book | title=Full-Time at The Dell |last= |first= | publisher= | isbn= |page=45}}
Although the minutes do not record the location of the new ground, it was common knowledge within the town that the new ground was situated
. . . in the dell that is not far from the County Ground, and nearer [[Southampton Central railway station|West Station]] and the town, and at the present time it is a narrow valley with a stone culvert running along the bottom. It will not be a large ground, but the natural banks on all sides will be a great help in arranging for the convenience of the spectators.{{cite book | title=Full-Time at The Dell |last= |first= | publisher= | isbn= |pages=46–47}}
The site on which the ground was built was described in [[Philip Brannon]]'s ''Picture of Southampton'', published in 1850, as "''a lovely dell with a gurgling stream and lofty aspens''";{{cite book |title= Picture of Southampton|last=Brannon |first=Philip |year= 1979|edition=reprint|origyear=First published 1850|publisher=Lawrence Oxley |location= Alresford|isbn=0-9501347-3-2 |page=72}} the stream is the Rollsbrook which flows out of [[Southampton Common]], running parallel to Hill Lane before now disappearing under Commercial Road and the Central Station, from where it is conduited under [[Southampton Docks]] into [[Southampton Water]]. The land had been purchased in the 1880s by the [[Didcot, Newbury and Southampton Railway]] to enable them to continue their line from [[Winchester]] via Twyford, Chandlers Ford, a tunnel at Chilworth and Shirley where it was to pass to the North East of what is now [[St James' Park, Southampton]] and [[St James' Church, Southampton|St. James' Church]]. From here the line would have travelled south across Hill Lane to run through the dell and onto an embankment leading to a viaduct over Commercial Road and the [[London and South Western Railway]] line before terminating on the Western Esplanade North of the Royal Pier.,Didcot, Newbury and Southampton Railway", Sands, T.B. {{ISBN|9780853610236}}Deposited Plans Hampshire Record Office Collection DP/384/1 Didcot Newbury and Southampton Junction Railway: deposited plan 1881 The dell was stripped of vegetation and the stream channelled into a [[Waterway|conduit]] with work started on the embankment, which survives behind property to the North of Commercial Road but was never used, and the viaduct which was part built but later demolished. The project was abandoned at this point and agreement reached to connected to the [[London and South Western Railway]] at Shawford Junction with running rights into Southampton. ==Construction== George Thomas, a fish merchant who had been appointed as a director of the limited company when it was formed in the summer of 1896, who lived in Shirley, saw the potential of the cleared site and purchased the land from the D.N.S.R. By the beginning of [[1898–99 Southampton F.C. season|the 1898–99 season]], Thomas had incurred expenditure of between £7,500 and £9,000 on acquiring and clearing the site, and erecting the new stands and had agreed an initial three-year lease to the football club at a rental of £250 p.a. The dell had been drained with 13,000 ft of pipe being laid, all draining into the central [[culvert]] formed from the Rollsbrook stream. The playing field had to be levelled and the ground made up and turfed ready for the opening of the new season. On completion, the stadium was described in the ''Southampton Observer'':
. . . the rising staging on the north side of the ground will hold 5,500 spectators, who have of course to stand up; the covered east and west stands will seat 4,000 spectators comfortably, and the staging and sloping bank on the south side will hold 15,000 spectators. This totals up to 24,500.{{cite book | title=Full-Time at The Dell |last= |first= | publisher= | isbn= |pages=52–53}}
At this stage, the new ground did not have an official name, with various names suggested including the "Fitzhugh Dell", the "Archer's Ground" and "Milton Park" but gradually the ground became known by default as "'''the Dell'''". ==Early days== The stadium was opened in September 1898, with the inaugural match on 3 September being against [[Brighton United F.C.|Brighton United]]. The first goal at the stadium was scored by [[Watty Keay]], with the others from [[Abe Hartley]], [[Jim McKenzie (footballer)|Jim McKenzie]] and [[Tom Smith (footballer born 1877)|Tom Smith]], as Southampton won 4–1.{{cite book | title=Match of the Millennium|last= Bull |first= David |author2=Brunskell, Bob | publisher=Hagiology Publishing | year=2000| isbn=0-9534474-1-3|pages=20–21}} It hosted an international match in 1901, as [[England national football team|England]] defeated [[Ireland national football team (1882–1950)|Ireland]] 3–0 in the [[1900–01 British Home Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-intres1900.html |title=England - International Results 1900-1919 - Details |work= |publisher=RSSSF |first=Barrie |last=Courtney |date=13 December 2012 |accessdate=22 January 2017}} ==Redevelopment== In 1927, the original West Stand was demolished (together with the club secretary's house) and the new West Stand was built. This was designed by [[Archibald Leitch]], one of the greatest football stand designers of the day, who had also designed stands at [[Fratton Park]], [[Roker Park]] and at [[Goodison Park]]. A year later, on the last day of the 1928–29 season a dropped cigarette caused a fire which destroyed the East Stand. A replacement stand was built which mirrored the West Stand, increasing the ground capacity to approximately 30,000. ==Wartime incidents== On 30 November 1940, a German bomb fell on the stadium during [[Southampton Blitz|the Blitz]], creating an 18-foot crater in the Milton Road penalty area.{{Cite web|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/club/history/|title=HISTORY|last=|website=www.saintsfc.co.uk|access-date=7 July 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/hampshire/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_9241000/9241143.stm|title=Southampton Blitz 70th anniversary remembered|date=30 November 2010|newspaper=BBC|access-date=7 July 2016}} While the pitch was being restored, Southampton had to play their remaining fixtures in 1940–41 away, although in February 1941, they played a "home" War Cup tie with [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] at [[Fratton Park]], [[Portsmouth]]. In March 1941, an explosion of munitions stored at the ground caused a major fire in the West Stand although this was rebuilt soon afterwards. At the start of the 1941–42 season they played their home games at Dew Lane, [[Eastleigh]], before the Dell was re-opened in October 1941. ==Post-war== [[Image:Inside The Dell. - geograph.org.uk - 111405.jpg|thumb|217px|right|Inside the Dell (Southampton draw 0–0 against Leicester City, March 1997)]] In 1950, the Dell became the first ground in England to have permanent floodlighting installed. The first game played under the lights was on 31 October 1950, in a friendly against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth & Boscombe Athletic]], followed a year later by the first "official" match under floodlights, a Football Combination (Reserve team) match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 1 October 1951. During the post-war years, huge crowds packed into the Dell. The attendance record was broken on 8 October 1969, when 31,044 watched Southampton lose 3–0 to a [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] team which included [[George Best]] and [[Bobby Charlton]]. The stadium hosted [[Football League First Division|First Division]] football for the first time in the [[1966-67 in English football|1966-67 season]], and would do so for all but four of the 35 seasons leading up to its closure. During this time, Southampton won the [[FA Cup]] in 1976, and achieved their highest league finish of second place in 1984. ==Further redevelopment== In the 1980s, there were several changes at the ground, with the makeshift ''chocolate boxes'' at the Milton Road end being replaced by a new stand used for family ticket holders a two level concrete structure. The standing areas under the East and West stands being fitted with bench seats, before the Dell became an all-seater stadium in the early 1990s in the wake of the [[Hillsborough disaster]] on 15 April 1989, which obliged all clubs in the top two English divisions had all-seater stadiums. New stands were erected at both ends of the stadium, but by the [[1993-94 in English football|1993–94 season]] the stadium now had a capacity of just over 15,000, the smallest in the top level of English football. The Milton Road Stand was notable for its wedge-like appearance. ==Final days== By this time, Southampton were looking for a new home. By the mid-1990s it seemed as if the search was over as the club announced plans to move to a new stadium at [[Monks Brook]] playing fields near the village of [[North Stoneham]], [[Eastleigh]].{{cite web|title=EBC Planning application Z/32214/003/00|url=http://www.eastleigh.gov.uk/fastweb/detail.asp?AltRef=Z/32214/003/00&ApplicationNumber=Z%2F32214%2F003%2F00&AddressPrefix=&submit2=Go|accessdate=3 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211041145/http://www.eastleigh.gov.uk/fastweb/detail.asp?AltRef=Z%2F32214%2F003%2F00&ApplicationNumber=Z%2F32214%2F003%2F00&AddressPrefix=&submit2=Go|archive-date=11 December 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} However, the club fell into a dispute with the local council about the lack of community facilities. Many people in Eastleigh were also unhappy with having another town's football club in their area. The dispute was resolved when the chairman, [[Rupert Lowe]], declared new plans for the club to move to a new [[St Mary's Stadium|32,000-seat stadium]], for a cost of £32 million, on Brittania Road on the banks of the [[River Itchen, Hampshire|River Itchen]]. The move was confirmed at the end of the [[1998-99 in English football|1998–99 season]] (when Southampton achieved a late escape from relegation for the sixth time in eight seasons) and work began soon afterwards. The new [[St Mary's Stadium]] was ready for the [[2001-02 in English football|2001–02 season]]. On 19 May 2001, midfielder [[Matthew Le Tissier]] (who retired from playing a year later) said goodbye to the stadium that had been host to his entire professional career by scoring a volley in the final minutes of the final league game securing a 3–2 win against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. Le Tissier thus has the distinction of scoring the last competitive goal at The Dell.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/1338713.stm|title=Le Tissier caps Dell farewell|publisher=[[BBC]] |date=19 May 2001 |accessdate=7 December 2009}} On 26 May, the club's fans said goodbye to the Dell by stripping all of its seats, the pitch and even an advertising board after Southampton's last game at the stadium, a 1-0 victory in a friendly against [[Brighton and Hove Albion]], the first and last opponents at the stadium. The last goal ever scored at the Dell was by [[Uwe Rösler]].{{cite book |title=Full-Time at The Dell |last= |first= | publisher= |isbn= |page=6}}{{cite web|url=http://www.southampton-mad.co.uk/news/TMNW/rosler_stakes_his_claim_13836/index.shtml | title = Rosler stakes his claim | date=15 August 2001|accessdate=8 April 2011|work=southampton-mad.co.uk}} The last confirmed hat-trick scored at the Dell was by Bryn Thomas on the 4th of May 2001 when the dell hosted the first 'Football Aid' charity event involving ex-Southampton players. During its 103-year life, the Dell had been home to Southampton during some of its finest moments – most of all during the [[FA Cup Final 1976|1976 FA Cup]] run, which finished with a win at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]]. The Dell was demolished later, completed on Friday 13 July 2001 by Portsmouth-based demolition company, Hughes & Salvidge.https://www.hughesandsalvidge.co.uk/news/final-whistle-blows-dell/ A housing estate was later built on the site by Barratt Homes. {{cite web|url=http://www.aap-arc.co.uk/pf_dell.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728041341/http://www.aap-arc.co.uk/pf_dell.html| archivedate=28 July 2011|accessdate=3 December 2013|title=The Dell - Project Portfolio - AAP Architecture}} The apartment blocks on the site bear the names of former Southampton players: * [[Bobby Stokes|Stokes]] Court * [[Ted Bates (footballer)|Bates]] Court * [[Matthew Le Tissier|Le Tissier]] Court * [[Danny Wallace (footballer)|Wallace]] Court * [[Mick Channon|Channon]] Court ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Dell (Southampton)}} *[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20010523/ai_n14383013 Memorable matches at The Dell – from The Independent] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_menu/past_future/pictures/past_stadiums/southampton_dell.shtml Pictures of the old stadium] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/hampshire/content/image_galleries/saints_archive_gallery.shtml?4 Picture of the old ''Chocolate Boxes''] *[http://www.footballgroundguide.com/old-grounds-and-stands/the_dell_southampton.htm Football Grounds Guide Article] {{Southampton F.C.}} {{Premier League venues}} {{Buildings in Southampton}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dell}} [[Category:Sport in Southampton]] [[Category:Southampton F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Premier League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hampshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1898]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2001]] [[Category:1898 establishments in England]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in the United Kingdom]]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/National Football League lore (2nd nomination)]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{About|"The Fumble" in Cleveland Browns lore|"The Fumble" in New York Giants lore|Miracle at the Meadowlands|other uses|Fumble (disambiguation)}} {{More footnotes|date=April 2009}}
In [[American football]], '''The Fumble''' was a play in the 1987 [[AFC Championship Game]] between the [[1987 Cleveland Browns season|Browns]] and [[1987 Denver Broncos season|Broncos]] on January 17, 1988 at [[Mile High Stadium]]. With 1:12 left in the game, Browns running back [[Earnest Byner]] fumbled on the Broncos 1 yard line while trying to score a touchdown to pull within one point. The Broncos went on to win 38–33 after taking an intentional safety.
==Background== [[File:1988 AFC Championship Game - Cleveland Browns at Denver Broncos 1988-01-17 (ticket).jpg|thumb|150px|A ticket for the AFC Championship Game between the Browns and the Broncos.]] The same two teams had met in the previous AFC Championship Game. That game also ended in victory for the Broncos and featured a famous five-minute, 98-yard touchdown drive led by quarterback [[John Elway]], known simply as [[The Drive]], to take the game into overtime.
During the game, the Broncos jumped to a 21–3 halftime lead, but Browns' quarterback [[Bernie Kosar]] led them back with four second-half touchdowns. By the middle of the fourth quarter, the game was tied at 31. The Broncos then took the lead on a long drive that ended with a 20-yard touchdown pass from Elway to running back [[Sammy Winder]], making it 38–31 with 6 minutes left. Cleveland responded by advancing the ball to Denver's 8-yard line with 1:12 left, setting the stage for the play that made this game one of the most famous in NFL lore.
==The play== Browns running back Earnest Byner took the handoff and appeared to be on his way to score the game-tying touchdown, but was stripped by Broncos defensive back [[Jeremiah Castille]] at the one-yard line. Denver recovered, gave the Browns an intentional [[Safety (American football score)|safety]], and went on to win 38–33.
==Reactions== On [[ESPN Classic]]'s "The Fumble, the Story of the 1987 AFC Championship", the Browns' then-head coach [[Marty Schottenheimer]] analyzed the play, showing that the fumble was not entirely Byner's fault. Schottenheimer stated: "The Browns' wide receiver #84, [[Webster Slaughter]] is supposed to take ten steps then block Castille to the outside. Instead, he wanted to watch the play."
Castille said: "I was thinking, 'I got burned the last time I tried to bump-and-run [Slaughter]', so instead I stepped back six-to-eight yards before the snap, so I could better see the play unfold. I saw it was a [[draw play]] and that Byner had the ball. I remember thinking that Byner ran all over us that entire second half, so there was no way I was going to tackle him. Instead, I went for the ball the whole time."
Schottenheimer continued: "Earnest never saw Castille coming. Earnest was the reason we were still in the game at that point. He had several heroic runs and catches over the course of the second half that allowed us to have a chance to tie the game at 38. All of these heroics, unfortunately, were overshadowed by a single draw play from the eight-yard line."
[[Dick Enberg]], the play-by-play announcer of the broadcast on [[NFL on NBC|NBC]], noted: "And wasn't it ironic that Denver got the ball back on the two-yard line? Wasn't it just one year ago where the Broncos were on their own two before putting together what became '[[The Drive]]'?"
[[ESPN Page2|ESPN Page Two]] writer [[Bill Simmons]] used "The Fumble" as an argument for why the Browns should be considered one of the most cursed franchises in sports. He also describes their fan base as "tortured" following this play. His article, "The Levels of Losing," appeared January 29, 2010.<ref>http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=simmons/100129&sportCat=nfl</ref>
==Aftermath== Despite being primarily remembered for "The Fumble", Byner had a relatively successful career. After spending another year with the Browns, he was traded to the [[Washington Redskins]] prior to the start of the [[1989 NFL season|1989 season]] for running back [[Mike Oliphant]]. In his five seasons with Washington, Byner was selected to play in the [[Pro Bowl]] twice (1990, 1991) and won a [[Super Bowl]] in the [[1991 NFL season|1991 season]]. In that season's [[Super Bowl XXVI]], he caught a touchdown pass in the second quarter, and the Redskins won, giving him the NFL Championship ring he could not win with the Browns.
He ended up going back to Cleveland for two more years, and finished his career in 1998, after spending two years with the transplanted [[Baltimore Ravens]]. In his 14 NFL seasons, Byner rushed for 8,261 yards, caught 512 passes for 4,605 yards, and scored 72 total touchdowns (56 rushing, 15 receiving, one fumble recovery). At the time of his retirement, Byner ranked within the NFL's top 30 all-time leaders in rushing attempts, rushing touchdowns, rushing yards, and total yards.
== Game Summary == {{Americanfootballbox | titlestyle=text-align:center; background:#eee | title=Game summary| |Road=Browns |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=21 |R4=9 |RT=33 |Home='''Broncos''' |H1=14 |H2=7 |H3=10 |H4=7 |HT=38 |stadium= [[Mile High Stadium]], [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] |time= 4:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/2:00 p.m. [[Mountain Time Zone|MST]] |TV=[[NFL on NBC|NBC]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] (play-by-play) and [[Merlin Olsen]] (color commentator) |referee= [[Jim Tunney (American football)|Jim Tunney]] |attendance= 76,197 |scoring= *'''Scoring''' **DEN – Nattiel 8 pass from Elway (Karlis kick) DEN 7–0 **DEN – Sewell 1 run (Karlis kick) DEN 14–0 **CLE – field goal Bahr 24 DEN 14–3 **DEN – Lang 1 run (Karlis kick) DEN 21–3 **CLE – Langhorne 18 pass from Kosar (Bahr kick) DEN 21–10 **DEN – Jackson 80 pass from Elway (Karlis kick) DEN 28–10 **CLE – Byner 32 pass from Kosar (Bahr kick) DEN 28–17 **CLE – Byner 4 run (Bahr kick) DEN 28–24 **DEN – field goal Karlis 38 DEN 31–24 **CLE – Slaughter 4 pass from Kosar (Bahr kick) T 31–31 **DEN – Winder 20 pass from Elway (Karlis kick) DEN 38–31 **CLE – Safety, Horan ran out of end zone DEN 38–33 }}
== Officials == *'''Referee:''' [[Jim Tunney (American football)|Jim Tunney]] (#32) *'''Umpire:''' Ben Montgomery (#117) *'''Head Linesman:''' Sid Semon (#109) *'''Line Judge:''' [[Ron Blum]] (#83) *'''Back Judge:''' Roy Clymer (#24) *'''Side Judge:''' Bill Quinby (#58) *'''Field Judge:''' Dick Dolack (#31) *'''Alternate:''' [[Jerry Seeman]] (#70)
==See also== *[[Cleveland sports curse]] *[[1987–88 NFL playoffs]] *[[The Drive]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *''Total Football: The Official Encyclopedia of the National Football League'' ({{ISBN|0-06-270174-6}})

{{For|the rugby football scoring attempt after a try|Conversion (rugby)}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} [[File:Kaipo-Noa Kaheaku-Enhada gets 2 pt conversion at 2007 Poinsettia Bowl 071220-N-9909C-003.jpg|thumb|Navy quarterback Kaipo-Noa Kaheaku-Enhada puts the ball over the goal line for a two-point conversion against the Utah Utes, 2007]] <!-- Commented out: [[Image:Th 2pts.jpg|frame|right|A famous two-point conversion in an [[National Football League|NFL]] game between the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] and [[Washington Redskins]] in [[2005 NFL season|2005]]. The Bucs won on the conversion 36-35.]] --> In [[American football|American]] and [[Canadian football]], a '''two-point conversion''' or '''two-point convert''' is a play a team attempts instead of kicking a one-point [[conversion (gridiron football)|conversion]] immediately after it scores a [[touchdown]]. In a two-point conversion attempt, the team that just scored must run a [[football play|play]] from scrimmage close to the opponent's goal line (5-yard line in amateur Canadian, 3-yard line in professional Canadian, 3-yard line in amateur American, 2-yard line in professional American; in professional American football, there is a small dash to denote the line of scrimmage for a two-point conversion; it was the previous line of scrimmage for a point after kick until 2014) and advance the ball across the goal line in the same manner as if they were scoring a touchdown. If the team succeeds, it earns two additional points on top of the six points for the touchdown, for a total of eight points. If the team fails, no additional points are scored. In either case, if any time remains in the half, the team proceeds to a [[Kickoff (American football)|kickoff]].
Various sources estimate the success rate of a two-point conversion to be between 40% and 55%, significantly lower than that of the extra point, though if the higher value is to be believed, a higher [[expected value]] is achieved through the two-point conversion than the extra point.<ref>412sportsanalytics "[https://412sportsanalytics.wordpress.com/2016/05/10/two-point-conversion-my-two-data-cents/ Two-Point Conversion: My two-data-cents,]", 2016.</ref><ref>K. Pelechrinis "[https://dtai.cs.kuleuven.be/events/MLSA16/papers/paper_1.pdf Decision Making in American Football: Evidence from 7 Years of NFL Data, in Machine Learning and Data Mining for Sports Analytics]", 2016.</ref>
==Adoption of rule== The two-point conversion rule has been used in [[college football]] {{nowrap|since [[1958 college football season|1958]],<ref name=wcfs>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dd5YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gPcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2650%2C2720134 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |title=WSC coach Sutherland favors new rule on point-after scores |date=January 13, 1958 |page=17}}</ref><ref name=twptconru>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oodOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sEIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6544%2C5041744 |newspaper=Ludington Daily News |location=(Michigan) |agency=Associated Press |last=Fullerton |first=Hugh, Jr. |title=Two-point conversion rule gets approval in AP poll |date=December 18, 1958 |page=10 }}</ref><ref name="time19581006">{{Cite magazine |date=1958-10-06 |title=The Two-Point Conversion |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,825522,00.html |dead-url=y |magazine=Time |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206170046/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,825522,00.html |archive-date=2009-02-06}}</ref>}} and more recently in Canadian amateur football and the [[Canadian Football League]] {{nowrap|([[1975 CFL season|1975]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=CFL History 1970s|url=https://www.cfl.ca/page/his_timeline_1970|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130316072247/http://www.cfl.ca/page/his_timeline_1970|publisher=Canadian Football League|archive-date=2013-03-16|accessdate=2016-08-02}}</ref>}} {{nowrap|In [[Overtime (sports)#American and Canadian football|overtime]]}} situations in college football, the two-point conversion is the mandatory method of scoring after a touchdown beginning with the third overtime, and in the CFL it is mandatory at any point in overtime.
The [[American Football League]] (AFL) used the two-point conversion during its ten-season existence from [[1960 AFL season|1960]] to [[1969 AFL season|1969]]. After the [[AFL-NFL merger|NFL merged with the AFL]], the rule did not immediately carry over to the merged league, though they experimented in 1968 with a compromise rule (see below). The NFL adopted the two-point conversion rule in {{nfly|1994}}, 25 years after the merger.<ref name=ooktpt>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mrwfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H9gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2578%2C2468571 |newspaper=Gadsden Times |location=(Alabama) |agency=Associated Press |last=Goldberg |first=Dave |title=Owners OK two-point conversion |date=March 23, 1994 |page=D1 }}</ref><ref>WiseGeek.com [http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-two-point-conversion.htm] Definition.</ref> [[Tom Tupa]] scored the first two-point conversion in NFL history, running in a faked extra point attempt for the [[Cleveland Browns]] in a game against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in the first week of the 1994 season. He scored a total of three such conversions that season, earning him the nickname "Two Point Tupa". That same season, the first successful two-point conversion in [[Super Bowl]] history came during [[Super Bowl XXIX]] when [[Los Angeles Chargers|San Diego Charger]] [[Mark Seay]] caught a pass thrown by [[Stan Humphries]].
The NFL's developmental league, [[NFL Europe]] (and its former entity, the [[World League of American Football]]), adopted the two-point conversion rule for its entire existence from 1991 through 2007.
[[Six-man football]] reverses the extra point and the two-point conversion: because there is no [[offensive line]] in that game variant, making kick protection more difficult, plays from scrimmage are worth one point but successful kicks are worth two. It is also reversed in many [[high school football]] and youth football leagues, since there are not often skilled kickers at that level.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} A variant of this, especially at the youth level, is to allow one point for a running conversion, two points for a passing conversion, and two points for a successful kick.
The [[Arena Football League]] has recognized the two-point conversion for its entire existence (in both its original 1987–2008 incarnation and its ongoing revival), allowing for either a play from scrimmage or a [[drop kick]] to be worth two points. (The additional extra point for a drop kick is unique to [[arena football]].)
In 1968, leading up to the [[AFL-NFL merger]], the leagues developed a radical "compromise" rule that would reconcile the fact that the NFL did not recognize the two-point conversion but the AFL did: the relatively easy [[extra point]] kick would be eliminated and only a play from scrimmage would score one point called a "Pressure Point". The rule would be used for the interleague matchups for that [[National Football League exhibition season|preseason]], and would not be tried again. Both the [[World Football League]] and the [[XFL]] revived this concept, making it a point not to institute a two-point conversion rule so as to eliminate the easy kick. What would constitute a two-point conversion in other leagues only counted one point in the AFL-NFL games, WFL, or XFL. The WFL called it the "Action Point", used after touchdowns which the WFL counted as seven points. However, the XFL later added a rule in the playoffs that allowed the scoring team to score two (or even three) points by successfully executing a play from a point farther from the opponent's end zone (two points if the team could score from the five-yard line and three points if they could score from the ten-yard line).
During the summer of 2014, the conversion by place kick was under review by the NFL. This new format would award seven points for a touchdown without an extra point attempt, eight points with a successful conversion by running or passing, and six points with an unsuccessful attempt. This new format was proposed because of the almost certain probability of making a conversion by place kick (1,260 out of 1,265 for the 2013 season).<ref>{{cite web|title=NFL Will examine eliminating the extra point|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/01/20/roger-goodell-nfl-will-explore-eliminating-the-extra-point/|publisher=NBC Sports|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> This proposal was never considered at the league owners' meeting in spring 2014; instead, the league used the first two weeks of its preseason for an experiment that moved extra point attempts back to the 20-yard line with the condition that if a team opted to attempt a two-point conversion instead, the line of scrimmage on the try would remain at the 2-yard line. The league adopted a slightly modified version of this rule starting with the 2015 season, with the line of scrimmage for extra-point kick attempts at the 15-yard line instead of the 20; that same year, the CFL also moved back its line of scrimmage for converts to the 25-yard line (while moving the scrimmage line for a two-point convert ahead two yards to the 3-yard line), thus making the length for an extra-point attempt the same length in both the NFL and CFL (taking into account the NFL positioning their goalposts on the end line, and the CFL's on the goal line).
==Defensive two-point conversion==
In American college, professional, and Canadian football (as well as, for a significant period of time, the [[Arena Football League (1987–2008)|Arena Football League]], where missed extra points are rebounded back into the field of play), a conversion attempt where the defense gains possession of the ball can be returned by the defense to the other end zone to give the ''defensive'' team two points. The team that scored the touchdown then kicks off as normal. This is rare because of the infrequent use of the two-point conversion and the rarity of blocked conversion kicks, combined with the difficulty of returning the ball the full length of the field. It has proven the winning margin in some games. Only once has a player scored two defensive two-point conversions in a game: Tony Holmes of the [[1998 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas Longhorns]] in a 1998 [[Big 12 Conference]] game against the [[1998 Iowa State Cyclones football team|Iowa State Cyclones]] on October 3.
On May 19, 2015, the NFL owners adopted a proposal to permit a defensive two-point conversion for the {{nfly|2015}} season. On May 20, 2016, the owners adopted a proposal called the 2 point fair play rule. This prevents a defense from getting a turnover during a 2 point conversion and then purposefully committing a “free” penalty to increase a chance at a 2 point return. If the defense is able to gain a takeaway and then commits a penalty, the opposing coach will have the option to accept the penalty and skip the kickoff. It has not yet been used in the NFL, but a similar rule has been used on two occasions in the CFL.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patra|first=Kevin|title=NFL moves extra point to 15-yard line for 2015 season|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000493347/article/nfl-moves-extra-point-to-15yard-line-for-2015-season|publisher=National Football League|date=May 19, 2015|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wilner|first=Barry|title=NFL to change extra-point kicks to longer distance|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/nfl-change-extra-point-kicks-longer-distance-221548213--nfl.html|agency=''Associated Press''|website=Yahoo! Sports|date=May 19, 2015|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref>
[[Stephone Anthony]] of the [[2015 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]] became the first NFL player to score a defensive two-point conversion; he returned a blocked extra point kick from [[Graham Gano]] of the [[2015 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] on December 6, 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25403612/saints-score-first-ever-blocked-extra-point-return-for-two-points |title=Saints first-ever team to run back a blocked extra point for two points |newspaper=CBS Sports |last=Dubin |first=Jared |date=6 December 2015 |accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref>
On December 4, {{nfly|2016}}, [[Eric Berry]] of the [[2016 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] became the first NFL player to return an interception for a defensive two-point conversion; it was thrown by quarterback [[Matt Ryan (American football)|Matt Ryan]] of the [[2016 Atlanta Falcons season|Atlanta Falcons]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Teicher|first1=Adam|title=Eric Berry has pick 6, 'pick 2' in emotional homecoming victory |url= http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/18204366/eric-berry-pick-2-lifts-kansas-city-chiefs-homecoming |accessdate= December 4, 2016 |publisher= ESPN |date= December 4, 2016}}</ref>
The NCAA has allowed defensive two-point conversions in college football since the [[1988 NCAA Division I-A football season#Rule changes|1988]] season.
High schools that follow the rules of the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]] (all U.S. high schools except those in [[Texas]] and [[Massachusetts]], which use NCAA rules instead) do not allow defensive runbacks of recovered conversion attempts, and any recovery of the ball by the defense during the try is immediately blown dead and ruled merely as "no good."
==Conversion safety== {{Further information|Conversion safety}} Rules in high school, college and professional football dictate that when a safety occurs during a two-point conversion or point-after kick (officially known in the rulebooks as a [[Conversion (gridiron football)|try]]), it is worth one point. It can be scored by the offense in college and professional football (following an NFL rule change in 2015) if the defense obtains possession of a live ball in the field of play, propels the ball (by carrying it or fumbling it) into its own end zone, and then is downed there with the defense in possession of the ball. This event has only occurred twice in NCAA [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] history. Before 2015, the only scenario in which a one-point safety could have been scored in the NFL would have involved the defense kicking or batting a loose ball out the back of the end zone without taking possession of it.<ref name="In Praise of the One-Point Safety">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/dailyfix/2013/01/04/2013-fiesta-bowl-oregon-kansas-state-one-point-safety/|title=In Praise of the One-Point Safety|last=Bialik|first=Carl|date=January 3, 2013|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=March 9, 2013}}</ref>
A conversion safety could be earned by the defense if the offense retreated with the ball all the way back into its own end zone; most plausibly this would involve a fumble at some point during the play. Two potential scenarios include an errant snap or a fumble that is bobbled repeatedly until the offensive team recovers the ball in, or bats the ball through, its own end zone (similar situations have been documented in regular play from scrimmage<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/college-football/news/watch-louisiana-tech-loses-87-yards-on-one-play-in-the-most-comical-fashion/|title=WATCH: Louisiana Tech loses 87 yards on one play in the most comical fashion|author=|date=|website=cbssports.com}}</ref> and are more likely in [[arena football]] with its much shorter, narrower and bounded field of play), or, in the college and professional game, a defender attempting a defensive two-point conversion, fumbling the ball and having the offensive team recover in their own end zone. Although such a conversion safety has never been scored by the defense, this rule provides the only way in American football that a team could finish the game with a score of one point. (Canadian football allows another one-point play called the [[single (football)|single]] or rouge).<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/sports/football/a-1-point-score-in-the-nfl-now-its-possible.html?ref=sports&_r=0 | title= N.F.L. Team Scoring Just 1 Point? Now It’s Possible | newspaper=New York Times | author=Victor Mather | date=September 10, 2015}}</ref>
The high school football rulebook acknowledges the conversion safety, awarding one point for it, but also immediately ends a play if the opposing team gains possession of the ball, a rule similar to the one the NFL used before 2015. Thus, any situation that requires the defense to gain possession of the ball could not result in a conversion safety in games where that rulebook is used.
== Choice of one- or two-point attempt == Coaches' choices of whether to attempt a one- or two-conversions will depend on a number of factors: the game's current scoreline, the amount of time remaining, and their assessment of their team's chances of success.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/when-to-go-for-2-for-real/|title=When To Go For 2, For Real|last=Morris|first=Benjamin|date=2017-02-03|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=2018-09-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
Analysis of historical data finds that the two-point conversion is successful about half the time, whereas one-point kicks are almost always successful. As such, the [[expected value]] of both options is roughly similar, with the critical factor being whether the chance of a successful two-point conversion is more or less than half that of a successful kick.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/more-nfl-teams-are-going-for-two-just-as-they-should-be/|title=More NFL Teams Are Going For Two — Just As They Should Be|last=Stuart|first=Chase|date=2016-11-15|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=2018-09-12|language=en-US}}</ref> However, the mathematics regarding maximizing a team's ''chances of winning'' are more complicated. For example, late in a game, a team that is one point up after a touchdown would gain little benefit from a one-point attempt, as, regardless of success, the team would still lose if the opposition scored a late [[field goal]]. In such a situation, the two-point conversion would be the better option, as this would mean — if successful — an opposition field goal would only tie the game.<ref name=":0" />
A more complicated scenario is when a team is trailing by eight points. The team could choose to go for two, because, if successful, the team could then kick an extra point following the next score to secure a win. On the other hand, if the two-point conversion fails, the team still has a chance to succeed on the next two-point conversion to get to fourteen. Mathematically, therefore, the minimum probability of converting a two-point try either on the first attempt (securing a win) ''or'' the second (securing a tie in regulation time) must be higher than the maximum probability of missing both (securing a loss). This occurs when the probability of missing both is 0.618 × 0.618, or 38.2%.<ref>The probability of failure to convert is "1 minus the probability of converting the two-point try", (1 − 0.382), or 0.618.</ref> As long as the probability of converting any individual two-point attempt is higher than 38.2% percent, it is optimal to adopt this strategy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://georgetownsportsanalysis.wordpress.com/2013/04/18/down-late-in-the-game-go-for-two/|title=Down Late in the Game? Go for Two|author=|date=18 April 2013|website=wordpress.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thegamedesigner.blogspot.com/2012/01/go-for-two.html|title=The Game Designer: Go For Two!|author=|date=16 January 2011|website=thegamedesigner.blogspot.com}}</ref> Notably, [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]] coach [[Darrell Royal]] successfully used this strategy to defeat [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]] in 1969's [[1969 Texas vs. Arkansas football game|Game of the Century]].
An analysis can be done for all situations, resulting in a table that can be consulted when a decision is needed.<ref name=":0" /> A chart made by [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] [[offensive coordinator]] [[Dick Vermeil]] in the early 1970s is one of the most well-known.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theredzone.org/Features/TwoPointConversionChart.aspx|title=Two Point Conversion Chart|author=|date=|website=theredzone.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2006-11-07-four-downs_x.htm?POE=SPOISVA|title=Four downs: Parcells deals with second-guessing - USATODAY.com|author=|date=|website=www.usatoday.com}}</ref>
In practice, two-point conversion attempts are rare, being done only after less than 1-in-10 touchdowns in the NFL.<ref name=":1" /> This proportion rose after the one-point kick was moved back to the 15-yard line, increasing the difficulty of scoring the single extra point.<ref name=":1" />
==Arena and other indoor football== In indoor versions of the sport, a two-point conversion is scored after a touchdown in the manner described above; that is, by running a play from scrimmage from the two-yard line in which the ball carrier succeeds in crossing the goal line while in possession of the ball, or the receiver makes a valid reception in the end zone or crosses the goal line in possession of the ball after having caught it in the field of play. In Arena football only, a successful [[drop kick]]ed conversion also counts as a two-point conversion.
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox film | name = Unbeatable | image = Unbeatable poster.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Dante Lam]] | producer = Candy Leung | writer = {{Plain list| * Dante Lam * Jack Ng * Fung Chi-fung }} | starring = {{Plain list| * [[Nick Cheung]] * [[Eddie Peng]] }} | music = [[Henry Lai Wan-man]] | cinematography = Kenny Tse | editing = Azrael Chung | studio = {{Plain list| * Bona Film Group * Bona Entertainment * Film Fireworks }} | distributor = Distribution Workshop {{small|(Hong Kong)}}
Tianjin Bona Cultural Media {{small|(China)}} | released = {{Film date|2013|06|18|Shanghai International Film Festival|2013|08|15|Hong Kong|2013|08|16|China}} | runtime = 116 minutes (Hong Kong)
122 minutes (China) | country = {{Plain list| * Hong Kong * China }} | language = Cantonese
Mandarin | budget = | gross = US$25,816,154{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&wk=2013W35&id=_fJIZHANUNBEATABL01 | title=JI ZHAN (UNBEATABLE) | accessdate=24 April 2014}} }} '''''Unbeatable''''' (激戰) is a 2013 Hong Kong–Chinese sports drama film directed by [[Dante Lam]]. The film had its premiere at the [[Shanghai International Film Festival]] on June 18, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/unbeatable|work=[[Film Business Asia]]|title=Unbeatable|author=Elley, Derek|date=June 25, 2013|accessdate=9 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701012524/http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/unbeatable|archivedate=1 July 2013|df=}} ==Plot== Ching Fai (Nick Cheung) is a former boxing champion who has struggled since his glory days, having gone to prison over involvement with the Triads due to financial problems and now working as a taxi driver. When Triad loan sharks torch his taxi and chase him down for money he owed, Fai decides to flee to Macau to avoid them. In Macau, Fai accepts a job offer from an old friend to work as an assistant in a gym, while renting a room with a feisty young girl Peidan (Crystal Lee), who has been taking care of her psychologically unstable mother (Mei Ting) since her four-year-old son drowned and her husband left her for another woman. At the gym, Fai meets a young man, Lin Siqi (Eddie Peng) who wishes to learn Mixed Martial Arts in order to join an upcoming MMA tournament, the "Golden Rumble", which offers the winner millions of dollars - his motivation for doing so is to help out his father, a businessman who had recently lost a fortune due to a failed "flipping" deal, which has turned him into a depressed drunkard. Fai agrees. For the next several months before the tournament, Fai has Lin follow a strict training regimen, and at the same time he develops a bond with Peidan and her mother. After the tournament begins, Lin struggles but is able to beat several opponents, making it into the semi-finals, impressing both Fai and Lin's father, but also gets the attention of the Triads. Later, while celebrating the Mid-Autumn Festival, loan sharks unexpectedly show up to attack Fai and Peidan's family. Fai fends them off, but Peidan is hurt in the process. As she is hospitalized, social services are also alerted to the fact that her mother is psychologically unfit to take care of a child. When she is told that Peidan's father is returning to take custody of Peidan, she violently assaults a social worker, immediately causing her to be placed into a mental hospital. At the same time, Lin faces his toughest opponent yet, and loses badly after his arm and neck are broken. Believing that he has "done nothing" for twenty years, Fai decides to join the tournament himself and trains vigorously for it, and is selected to enter the finals. Peidan's father also comes to meet Fai, and although Fai feels indifferent towards him at first, the father tells him that Peidan has agreed to live with him, but only if Fai wins in the tournament. After a brutal fight watched by many, including Lin in the hospital, Fai ultimately emerges victorious (by taking advantage of his easily dislocated right shoulder), and Lin is so excited over the victory that he leaps out of his wheelchair, cured. With his newly earned fortune, Fai pays off his loans and meets Peidan one last time, while also continuing to visit Peidan's mother. He later meets a now recovered Lin, and the two joke about the injuries that they have each endured in the ring. ==Cast== * [[Nick Cheung]] as Ching Fai * [[Eddie Peng]] as Lin Siqi * Crystal Lee as Liang Peidan * [[Mei Ting]] as Wang Mingjun * Philip Keung as Yeung Hin-sun * Li Feier as Coco (only appears in China Mainland version) * [[Jack Kao]] as Lin Yuanxiang * [[Andy On]] as Li Zitian * [[Will Liu]] as Rock Kong * Liu Chunwei as young Ching Fai * Michelle Lo as Sandy Lo * [[Stephen Au]] as Master Kwan, Ching Fai's master * [[Noel Leung]] as psychiatrist * [[Wang Baoqiang]] as Boss Chan ==Production== An early title English-language title for the film was ''MMA''. The film was written by Jack Ng, Dante Lam and Fung Chi-fung. Ng and Lam had previously worked together on ''[[The Viral Factor]]'', ''[[The Stool Pigeon (2010 film)|The Stool Pigeon]]'', and ''[[Fire of Conscience]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/the-viral-factor|work=Film Business Asia|title=The Viral Factor|author=Elley, Derek|date=February 2, 2012|accessdate=9 July 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/the-stool-pigeon|work=Film Business Asia|title=The Stool Pigeon|author=Elley, Derek|date=September 22, 2010|accessdate=9 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115025824/http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/the-stool-pigeon|archivedate=15 November 2010|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/fire-of-conscience|work=Film Business Asia|title=Fire of Conscience|author=Elley, Derek|date=May 14, 2010|accessdate=9 July 2013}} ==Release== The film had premiered at the [[Shanghai International Film Festival]] on June 18, 2013. It was released in China on August 16, 2013. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== Clarence Tsui of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' writes, "It’s this mix of tears and laughter amidst the blood, sweat and broken necks that makes Unbeatable an enjoyable vehicle."{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/unbeatable-gik-jeen-ji-zhan-604014|title=Unbeatable|date=12 August 2013|author=Clarence Tsui|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}} Andrew Chan of the [[Film Critics Circle of Australia]] writes, "''Unbeatable'' is one of those films that never stops to excite, entertain, inspire and finally understand. It is an accomplished effort from a director very much in his prime and also bringing a veteran actor to even greater heights."{{cite web|url=http://thehkneo.com/blog/?p=4174|title=Unbeatable|date=29 August 2013|author=Andrew Chan|publisher=''[HK Neo Reviews]''}} Kevin Ma of LoveHKFilm states that "with a career-best performance by Nick Cheung, a script infused with great humor and MMA scenes that will please action fanboys, this sports drama is Dante Lam’s best film since ''[[The Beast Stalker]]'' and easily his most purely enjoyable to date. ''Unbeatable'' offers nothing new, but it’s solid genre entertainment." He informs audiences that "''Unbeatable''’s selling point is mixed martial arts, but it’s really a character-driven drama about three troubled souls in Macau," using the words "uplifting" and "inspiring" to describe the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.lovehkfilm.com/reviews_2/unbeatable.html|title=Unbeatable|date=June 2013|author=Kevin Ma|publisher=''LoveHKFilm''}} ===Box office=== By 1 September 2013, ''Unbeatable'' has earned over HK$32.5 million in the box office of Hong Kong. It is the highest-grossing film of the summer and also the highest grossing locally produced film of 2013. Lead actor Cheung Ka-Fai said he will appear in eight cinemas to thank the cinema goers' support and drive the box office results further up.{{zh-hk}}{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130903/-15-3056917/1.html|title=《激戰》狂收3255萬 張家輝謝票|date=3 September 2013|publisher=''Sina Hong Kong (Ming Pao)''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922143938/http://news.sina.com.hk/news/20130903/-15-3056917/1.html|archivedate=22 September 2013|df=}} Near the end of September, the film has made over HK$43 million.{{zh-hk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hkfilmart.com/boxofficedetail.asp?lang=cn&wbid=961|title=每週詳細票房 2013年9月16日 - 2013年9月22日|accessdate=2 October 2013|publisher=Hong Kong Filmart}} ===Awards=== {{Anchor|Accolades|Awards}} {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan=4|[[33rd Hong Kong Film Awards]]{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000330/2014|title=33rd Hong Kong Film Awards|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=18 February 2016}} |- ! Nominee ! Awards ! Results |- | - || Best Film ||{{nom}} |- | [[Dante Lam]] || Best Director ||{{nom}} |- | [[Nick Cheung]] || Best Actor ||{{won}} |- | [[Eddie Peng]] || Best Supporting Actor ||{{nom}} |- | Crystal Lee || Best Supporting Actress ||{{nom}} |- | [[Dante Lam]], Chi Fung Fung, Wai Lun Ng || Best Screenplay ||{{nom}} |- | Kenny Tse || Best Cinematography ||{{nom}} |- | Phyllis Cheng || Best Sound Design ||{{nom}} |- | Wai Chiu Chung || Best Film Editing ||{{nom}} |- | [[Henry Lai Wan-man]] || Best Original Film Score ||{{nom}} |- | Chi Wah Ling || Best Action Choreography ||{{nom}} |- !colspan=4|2014 [[Hong Kong Film Critics Society Awards]]{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000330/2014|title=33rd Hong Kong Film Society Awards|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=18 February 2016}} |- ! Nominee !! Awards !! Nominee ! Awards ! Results |- |[[Dante Lam]] ||Best Chinese Director ||{{won}} |- |[[Nick Cheung]] ||Best Chinese Film Actor ||{{won}} |} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|3003668}} {{Dante Lam}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:Hong Kong films]] [[Category:Chinese films]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts films]] [[Category:2010s sports films]] [[Category:Martial arts tournament films]] [[Category:Sports in fiction]] [[Category:Cantonese-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Dante Lam]] [[Category:Chinese sports films]] [[Category:Hong Kong sports films]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Unión Tarija | image = [[Image:Union Central.png|100px]]| fullname = Club Unión Tarija | nickname = | founded = April 8, 1980 | ground = [[Estadio IV Centenário]]
[[Tarija, Bolivia|Tarija]], [[Bolivia]]| capacity = 15,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Primera B]]| season = 2006| position = 12th| pattern_la1=_pana1011h |pattern_b1=_panathinaikosh2010|pattern_ra1=_pana1011h |pattern_sh1=_adidaswhite |pattern_so1=_3_stripes_white| |leftarm1=008000|body1=008000|rightarm1=008000|shorts1=008000|socks1=008000| |pattern_la2=_pana1011a |pattern_b2=_panathinaikosa2010|pattern_ra2=_pana1011a |pattern_sh2=_adidasonwhite| |pattern_so2=_3_stripes_green| |leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=008000|socks2=FFFFFF| }} '''Unión Tarija''' is a [[Bolivia]]n [[Football (soccer)|football]] team playing at Tarija Primera A, the 2nd division regional league. It is based in [[Tarija, Bolivia|Tarija]]. Their home stadium is [[Estadio IV Centenário]]. The team played in the [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano]] between 1999 and 2006. == History == The Club was founded on April 8, 1980 as the Club Unión Central.{{cite book|title=An Encyclopedia of Football in Bolivia – 1914 to 1998|last=Vanauskas|first=Laura|publisher=Heart Books – Belgium|date=1999|page=192|work=The Clubs – Club Union Central, details and references to formation}} == National honours == *'''[[Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano|First Division – Professional Era]]: 0''' *'''[[Bolivian Football Regional Championships|Second Division, Copa Simón Bolivar]]: 1''' ::1998 == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Liga de Fútbol Profesional Boliviano}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Club Union Central}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bolivia|Union Central]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1980]] [[Category:1980 establishments in Bolivia]] {{bolivia-sport-stub}} {{SouthAm-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''William Brazier''' (1755 at Cudham, [[Kent]] – 7 October 1829 at Cudham) was a noted English [[cricket]]er of the late 18th century who played mostly for [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]].
Brazier is first recorded in the 1774 season and was probably a genuine debutant in that year, being aged 19 at the time. He was a good all rounder who bowled fast and was a powerful hitter.
He played for a left-handed team in 1790 but S&B says he was right-handed. He did not play during the years 1777 to 1781 inclusive, possibly because he was in the armed forces or otherwise employed away from Kent. According to S&B, he was a farmer at Cudham.
William Brazier made 53 known first-class appearances from 1774 to 1794 but he continued to play village cricket until 1819 when he would have been 64 years old.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox sports team | name = Woodville Lacrosse Club | color1 = green | color2 = gold | logo = WoodvilleLacrosseClubLogo.png | logo_size = | alt = | caption = | full_name = | nicknames = Warriors | sport = [[Lacrosse]] | founded = {{Start date|df=yes|1899|02|24}} | folded = | current = | league = Lacrosse SA | conference = | division = | history = | arena = Findon Oval | ballpark = | stadium = | city = [[Adelaide]] | colors = | colours = green and gold | owner = | president = | coach = | manager = | gm = | championships = 1904, 1931, 1932, 1949, 1955, 1958, 1959, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2005, 2007, 2008 | conference_titles = | division_titles = | playoff_berths = | anthem = | cheerleaders = | dancers = | mascot = | fanclub = | broadcasters = | media = | uniforms = | branches = | members = | blank_label = | blank_data = | blank_label1 = | blank_data1 = | blank_label2 = | blank_data2 = | blank_label3 = | blank_data3 = | website = {{URL | www.warriorslax.com }} }}
The '''Woodville Lacrosse Club''' was founded in 1899<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article87783753 |title=Lacrosse. |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Adelaide)|The Chronicle]] |location=Adelaide |date=18 March 1899 |accessdate=14 August 2014 |page=32 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and is located in the north western suburbs of [[Adelaide]].
In 1903, the name of the club was changed to Port Adelaide,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4928814 |title=LACROSSE. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 February 1903 |accessdate=22 July 2014 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> by which it was known until 1966, until becoming once again known as Woodville.
== Premierships == As Port Adelaide, the Club had early success in 1904, finishing the season ahead of Sturt, who were the dominant club in South Australia at the time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article88073815 |title=Lacrosse. |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Adelaide)|The Chronicle]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 August 1904 |accessdate=14 August 2014 |page=21 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Port Adelaide had additional success in 1931<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article61563280 |title=Lacrosse Premiership Won by Port Adelaide. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=29 August 1931 |accessdate=14 August 2014 |page=14 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and 1932,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59832516 |title=Port Beat Minor Premiers For Lacrosse Title. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=24 September 1932 |accessdate=14 August 2014 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> before having a golden era in the 1950s, featuring in 10 of 12 grand finals and winning four of them. There was a 39-year drought before success returned to the Club, this time as Woodville, with 8 premierships in 11 years including five in a row from 1998 to 2002.
'''A Grade Premierships''': * 1904, 1931, 1932, 1949, 1955, 1958, 1959, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2005, 2007, 2008<ref>[[List of South Australian Lacrosse Premiers]]</ref>
== National Awards == Australian Lacrosse Council (now [[Australian Lacrosse Association|ALA]]) '''Fellows Award''': * 1995 – Kenneth Forrest
'''[[List of Australian Lacrosse best and fairest players|Isaachsen Trophy]]''' winners: * 1967 – Glenn Bowyer * 2002 – [[Peter Inge]] * 2004, 2006 – James Inge
'''Brady Award''' (Best and Fairest at the [[List of Australian Lacrosse national champions|National Carnival]]): * 1959 – Ralph Turner * 1998 – Aaron Sargent * 2005 – [[Peter Inge]] * 2010 – Stefan Guerin
[[List of Australian Club Lacrosse national champions|Australian Club Champions]] * 2008
== Notable players == One of Woodville's finest players is [[Peter Inge]], who represented [[Australia men's national lacrosse team|Australia]] in [[World Lacrosse Championship|World Championships]] in 1998, 2002 and 2006 as well as the national [[Under-19 World Lacrosse Championships#ILF U-19 World Championship|Under 19]] team in 1996. At the [[2002 World Lacrosse Championship]], Inge was named in the All-Star Team. In 2003, Inge became the first Australian and first player without [[NCAA]] experience to be drafted to the professional [[Major League Lacrosse]] competition in the United States, where he was selected for the [[Boston Cannons]]. He played at Boston for three years before spending his fourth and final year in the MLL at the now-defunct [[San Francisco Dragons]].
